title: Four-Year Construction Rule Exceeded

scenario_info.name: Four-Year Construction Rule Exceeded
scenario_info.description: Brian purchases vacant land and builds his home, but construction takes 5 years due to delays. Because the 4-year construction rule is exceeded, the land can only be treated as his main residence for the 4 years immediately before the completed dwelling became his main residence.

expected_result.notes: After 50% discount. First year of land ownership not covered by 4-year rule.

applicable_rules: If construction exceeds 4 years, MRE only applies for 4 years before completion
Land was not MR for first year (excess beyond 4-year limit)
14.46% of gain is taxable (first year of land ownership)

property_history.description: Moved in as main residence. 4-year construction rule only covers back to 1 Jan 2019.

properties.notes: Partial exemption (85.54%). Construction took 5 years, exceeding the 4-year rule. Land treated as main residence only from 1 Jan 2019 (4 years before move-in). First year of ownership (2018) is not covered = 14.46% taxable. Taxable gain after 50% discount: $13,340.

user_query: I bought vacant land in 2018 and built my home, but construction took 5 years due to delays. I finally moved in at the start of 2023. Now I'm selling. What's my CGT position?
